field.name: Description - copyright
field.definition: information on copyright or conditions of use for a resource in a learning or educational setting

dos.practice: Search the resource for an explicit copyright statement to enter into this field. It may be as simple as "Copyright, 2000", or it may be a more lengthy text statement.
Indicate copyright restrictions or lack thereof and/or whether the resource is free and clear for general use.
If the copyright statement is extremely long, edit it to convey the most pertinent information and then include a statement saying please see the resource directly to obtain the latest information.

If the copyright statement is difficult to understand or is not very readable, edit it to convey the most pertinent information and then include a statement saying please see the resource directly to obtain the latest information.
Encode the copyright symbol as string composed of: an ampersand, the pound sign, the number 169 followed by a semicolon with no spaces between all the symbols and number.
Website URLs with more information may be included but they will not be hyperlinked in library displays.

donts.practice: Do not put quotes around copyright information.

examples.practice: May be used in an educational setting as long as credit to NASA is given.

otherPractice.practice: If this field cannot be readily determined, enter the statement "Copyright and other restrictions information is unknown" as the content for this field (excluding the quotes).
Enter characters like the ampersand apostrophe, double quote, less than and greater than sign by using their respective html references of &, ', ", < and >.

otherPractice.header: Want to use other special characters like ©, é, ñ or ê? Do this:
otherPractice.practice: Enter special characters and symbols using their entity references numbers. For the copyright symbol this means entering an ampersand symbol followed by the pound sign followed by the number 169 followed by a semicolon.

documentation.example: May be used in an educational setting as long as credit to NASA is given.
